protocol.text: Arabidopsis thaliana plants were cultivated in a growth chamber under short-day conditions (8 h of light, 120 µE) at 22°C and 16°C during the dark period (16 h).
The base of the first emerging main inflorescence stalk (3-5 cm) of intact plants was wounded with a syringe needle, mock-inoculated and grown for another three hours.
VSN (variance stabilization normalization, reference: Huber et al. (2002) Bioinformatics 18: suppl. 1, S96-S104)
Total RNA was extracted, including digestion of DNA, from plant tissue samples by using the RNeasy Plant Mini Kit according to manufacturer's protocol (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany).

Arabidopsis thaliana plants were cultivated in a growth chamber under short-day conditions (8 h of light, 120 µE) at 22°C and 16°C during the dark period (16 h). Agrobacteria were grown on YEB plates over night.

The base of the first emerging main inflorescence stalk (3-5 cm) of intact plants was wounded with a syringe needle and inoculated with A. tumefaciens strain C58. Agrobacteria were scratched from the surface of an agar plate with a bent pipette tip by preventing contamination with medium and evenly spread on the wounded inflorescence stalk area immediately after wounding. Inoculated plants were grown for another three hours.

Arabidopsis thaliana plants were cultivated in growth chambers under short-day conditions (8 h of light, 120 µE) at 22°C and 16°C during the dark period (16 h). Agrobacteria were grown on YEB plates over night.

The base of the first emerging main inflorescence stalk (3-5 cm) of intact plants was wounded with a syringe needle and inoculated with A. tumefaciens strain GV3101. Agrobacteria were scratched from the surface of an agar plate with a bent pipette tip by preventing contamination with medium and evenly spread on the wounded inflorescence stalk area immediately after wounding. Inoculated plants were grown for another three hours.
